Award.AwardTitle: SI2-CHE: Collaborative Research: Developing First Principles Monte Carlo Methods for Reactive Phase and Sorption Equilibria in the CP2K Software Suite
Award.AbstractNarration:
An international research team consisting of Ilja Siepmann, Ben Lynch (University of Minnesota), Neeraj Rai (Mississippi State University), Troy Van Voorhis (Massachusetts Institute of Technology), Ben Slater (University College London), Michiel Sprik (University of Cambridge), Adam Carter (Edinburgh Parallel Computing Centre), JÃ¼rg Hutter (University of Zurich), I-Feng Kuo (Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory), Christopher Mundy (Pacific Northwest National Laboratory), Joost VandeVondele (ETH Zurich), and Rodolphe Vuilleumier (University Pierre & Marie Curie Paris) is collaborating to develop and implement new theoretical methods in the CP2K computational chemistry software suite. These new methodologies enable the predictive modeling of reactive multi-phase systems, including free energy landscapes and product yields, where the system interactions are described by Kohn-Sham density functional theory with van der Waals and hybrid functionals. Markov chain Monte Carlo approaches utilizing smart moves with asymmetric underlying matrices, such as the aggregation-volume-bias and configurational-bias Monte Carlo methods, and the Gibbs ensemble framework are employed for efficient exploration of the phase space for reactive single- and multi-phase equilibria in bulk and in confinement. The U.S. based research team is supported jointly by the Chemistry Division in MPS and the Office of Cyberinfrastucture. Funds for the UK based research team are provided by the EPSRC.

The software infrastructure is advanced by the development of efficient and accurate methodologies for reactive phase and sorption equilibria that are applicable to chemical processes in diverse science and engineering applications. The extensively validated methodologies will be incorporated into the open-source CP2K software suite to make them available to a large user base. The new software can be used to identify optimal reaction conditions and separation processes for sustainable chemistry. The collaborative research team plans to use the new software for the investigation of reactive processes that address critical needs of society (fertilizers for food supply, fuels from renewable sources, and environmentally benign chemical processes).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This international SISI team has developed and implemented new theoretical methods in the CP2K computational chemistry software suite in order to add novel sampling capabilities for reactive phase and sorption equilibria. This software will be transformative for understanding and predicting free energy landscapes and product yields for reactive multi-phase systems and for identifying optimal reaction conditions and separation processes for sustainable chemistry.

Our collaborative research has led to innovations in computational thinking by synergistically developing and implementing problem-driven, efficient, and scalable sampling algorithms and accurate electronic structure methods (vdW and hybrid functionals) to enable predictive first principles Monte Carlo (FPMC) simulations for reactive single- and multi-phase equilibria, where the system interactions are described by Kohn-Sham density functional theory, and to apply them to advance molecular-level understanding and design of a multitude of sustainable chemical processes. This novel MC methodology overcomes the timescale limitations of first principles molecular dynamics simulations and the reliance on pre-specified reactions and ideal-gas molecular partition functions utilized in force field based reaction ensemble MC simulations by treating chemical conversions as a special type of aggregation that can be sampled expediently by Markov chain MC approaches utilizing smart moves with asymmetric underlying matrices, such as the aggregation-volume-bias and configurational-bias MC methods. Coupling these sampling strategies with the Gibbs ensemble framework allows for investigation of reactive equilibria involving multiple phases including microporous sorbents.

In addition to the algorithm and software development, the team has applied the reactive RxFPMC methodology to probe three systems of significant importants for the chemical sciences. First, the reaction equilibrium for nitrogen and oxygen mixtures at conditions found in lightning strikes and explosive events was simulated and the results show increased NO yield when oxygen is present in slight excess and the formation of triatomic NO2 and N2O. Second, the reaction equilibrium of the sour gases H2S and CO2 that need to be removed from natural gas during the sweetening process, was investigated and the simulations demonstrate that adsorption in cation-exchanged zeolites leads to formation of toxic OCS. Third, the adsorption of CO2 and N2 at flue gas conditions in Mg-MOF-74, a metal-organic framework with undercoordinated metal sites, was investigated and the simulations show the sorbents potential for highly selective carbon capture due to chemisorption of CO2 to the open metal site.  For all three systems, the simulation data are in excellent agreement with experimental data.
